title: What is the 'Mistral'? - Quora
tags: English Word Definitions, Terminology, and Jargon

response.answer_text: 1. a strong cold dry wind that blows through the Rhône valley and S France to the Mediterranean coast, mainly in the winter 2. the class of board used in international windsurfing competitions, weighing 15kg and measuring 372cm × 64cm 3. Mistral is an ISO 9001:2015 & AS9100D certified organisation that offers a comprehensive, end-to-end portfolio of solutions that address the emerging needs of reliable and intelligent devices driving innovation and business transformation. Mistral is an R&D center recognized by the Department of Science and Technology, Govt. of India for embedded technology to innovate, utilize latest technologies and development methodologies to help customers and ODMs design cutting-edge, innovative products across various domains. Mistral operates in USA, Canada, Europe, Singapore and South Africa regions and is headquartered in Bangalore with regional offices in USA (California) and India (Delhi, Hyderabad).

Mistral- The mistral is a strong, cold, northwesterly wind that blows from southern France into the Gulf of Lion in the northern Mediterranean. Causes- This cold, dry wind usually causes a period of cloudless skies and luminous sunshine, which gives the mistral its reputation for making the sky especially clear. ... The mistral noir occurs when the Azores High is extended and draws in unusually moist air from the northwest. Mitral Come from - Mistral. Strong, cold, dry and squally northerly wind that blows offshore with great frequency along the Mediterranean coast from northern Spain to northern Italy, and that is particularly frequent in the lower Rhone valley in south-eastern France blowing way out into the Golfe du Lion.

“The Mistral is a strong, cold, northwesterly wind that blows from southern France into the Gulf of Lion in the northern Mediterranean. It produces sustained winds often exceeding 66 km/h (41 mph), sometimes reaching 185 km/h (115 mph). It is most common in the winter and spring, and strongest in the transition between the two seasons. Periods of the wind exceeding 30 km/h (19 mph) for more than sixty-five hours have been reported.” Mistral (wind) - Wikipedia Here is a site about the ‘Winds of the world:’ Winds of the world
